posts.name: Julius
posts.cooked: I'm often conflicted about variable naming—whether to prefer either overly verbose names or short abbreviations. Which is better? What's your approach? Especially in collaborative environments, this can be frustrating.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Picking variable names is akin to selecting notes during jazz improvisation—there are options, but choosing the right ones requires skill and understanding. Naming internal components in software is essentially communication, ensuring clarity among team members and oneself. Variable names must be easily understandable to prevent confusion and wasted effort interpreting their meanings. While longer names may aid comprehension, they come with drawbacks, such as slower typing and redundancy. Team preferences vary widely, making collaboration essential to align on naming conventions. When code reviewing, involving another developer ensures mutual agreement on variable significance, offering a stronger basis for validating names than unilateral decisions alone. Here's my recommended approach:

1. Workshop naming conventions with your entire development team beforehand to gauge team sentiment toward preferred styles.
2. Encourage ongoing code reviews during the project to refine and validate naming choices promptly.

posts.name: Jeffrey Morris
posts.cooked: Just gonna drop this here. Not entirely relevant, but I figured you'd want to watch it.

posts.name: Jimmy McCosker
posts.cooked: https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/code_quality.png, see also xkcd 1695, 1833, 1926, and 2138

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: DTQEVXLAfc4

posts.name: Rhett Adam
posts.cooked: I always follow the philosophy of long variable names in snake-case format when programming my personal projects. Even though no-one else is collaborating on the same project, I still prefer it to be readable to my future self. Short variable names might save you a few seconds of typing or milliseconds of compute time, but ultimately, for the sake of yourself and others, use readable, sequential variable names.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Name things after what they do rather than what they are Similarly avoid naming things after design patterns like FooFactory or FooStrategy if you've implemented the pattern well its apparent from the API contract and semantic names what the pattern is Name things after what they do rather than how they do it As your code grows you might develop related functions or variables with similar names that differ only by small implementation details These names can leak into the public API causing abstraction leakage or become distracting When this happens consider creating a generic function with a configuration parameter to specify implementation details This avoids namespace pollution and explicit control over abstraction leakage Try to use names from the audience's problem space rather than the author's solution space Writing code requires understanding your audience Names that are convenient for you during writing may not be suitable for users or maintainers who encounter the code later Use shorter names for locals than for globals Locals benefit heavily from context so they don't need extensive names while globals must be more descriptive Short single-letter variable names are common in local scopes especially in functional programming

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked: Use names from the audience’s problem-space rather than the author’s solution-space. This approach is similar to the XY problem for variable naming (and is great advice). As for whether short or long variable names should be used, my preference is to correlate a variable’s scope with how much work I put into choosing a lengthy name. I’ll use long, descriptive names for public fields, methods, and parameter names in public methods, but I’ll also let myself use shorter names for variables with smaller scope. Private fields and parameters for private methods are a bit of a middleground to me, but I err on the side of longer names because really, it’s unlikely you’re ever going to type out the whole variable name more than twice if you have a reasonably modern editor. One more note: I find that WPILib is a good example of naming done right. I often find myself perusing its source code, and I think the WPILib devs do a great job at naming variables (among plenty other things but those don’t correlate to this thread).
If I can hear myself typing for more than a quarter-second, the name is too long, and I will shorten it to the first letters of each word. For int iterators, I go in the order of i, v, g, h, j, k.

posts.name: Drew Williams
posts.cooked: Use a linter/formatter that will take care of the casing for you. For actual names, I like to be as descriptive as possible given the scope of the variable. We aren’t limited to super small screens so there isn’t a reason to make super short variable names.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: For int iterators i go in the order of i, v, g, h, j, k. This statement intrigued me… why that order specifically? I’m used to simply i/j/k for nested iterators, so I’m curious where v/g/h comes in for you.
In a very cursed time and place stems from its very nature

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Ah, yes, of course! For iterating over maps or dictionaries, I typically use key-value pairs (k, v). When dealing with numerically indexed arrays, using i, v would also make sense. However, I wouldn’t use 'i' then 'v' etc., for nested loop indexes-iterators, but I can see the thought process behind it.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
For integer loop control variables that have a weak meaning, I use **i**, **j**, **k**, **m**, and **n** (skipping **l** because it looks like a 1 in Courier and other typewriter-based fonts). In MATLAB, I will start with **j** because I use the built-in **i** from time to time for **√−1**. Of course, if I'm looping over rows and columns, I may well use **row** and **col**. For iteration over strings and other objects with a weak meaning, I usually go with **a**, **b**, **c**, etc.

I totally agree with these three from @oblarg:
1. Name things after what they do, rather than what they are.
2. Try to use names from the audience’s problem-space, rather than the author’s solution-space.
3. Use shorter names for locals than for globals.

I don’t get this one. I hope I just misunderstand what you’re saying:

I get this for methods, function handles, and the like which should usually be verbs, but are you suggesting naming the drivetrain object **MoveTheRobotAround** and a manipulator **HandleTheGamePiece**?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: "Drive" is a perfectly fine name for the thing that drives the robot. Most natural languages are very flexible about parts-of-speech; you can "noun" a verb or "verb" a noun.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked: Can you give an example or two of what you are advocating against? Thanks

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: There’s one in the original post. If you have a local array of subsystems and you’re tempted to name it `subsystemArray`, maybe rethink that. We know it’s an array of subsystems immediately on mouseover; that name tells us nothing.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
Unpopular among English speakers, it is not recommended at all, though it exists widely: Pinyin Initial Variable Naming (拼音首字母命名法).  
For example, "Flywheel speed" can be translated as "摩擦轮速度 (mó cā lún sù dù)", so the variable name would be mclsd.  
I have used this naming scheme in debugging many pieces of code.

posts.name: GaryVoshol
posts.cooked:
For int iterators i go in the order of i, v, g, h, j, k. Us old FORTRAN coders (there are a few around) are cringing because some of those choices aren’t “real” integer variable names. Don’t do what one of my colleagues had to try to unravel. Someone programmed in FORTRAN who didn’t really know FORTRAN. They knew BASIC. So every variable name was 1 or 2 characters long: t, tt, t1, t2, … all had something to do with time. It was so hard to follow that she gave up and rewrote it completely.  

So I agree with many other posts, make variable names longer and descriptive.

posts.name: Justin Nesselrotte
posts.cooked: I agree wholeheartedly with these suggestions. One challenge I’ve encountered is the difficulty of thinking about the audience problem space, particularly as a junior developer, though even senior developers face similar hurdles. To improve my approach, I find it helpful to design class names that explicitly reflect their purpose. For instance, avoiding overly broad or ambiguous names ensures clarity. Additionally, using explicit variable names rather than relying solely on simple types enhances readability and reduces potential misunderstandings. Finally, I believe in the importance of continuous learning through resources like Domain-Driven Design and Ubiquitous Language to refine my coding practices.
